020import static com.google.common.util.concurrent.Platform.rethrowIfErrorOtherThanStackOverflow;
021import static java.lang.Boolean.parseBoolean;
022import static java.lang.Integer.toHexString;
023import static java.lang.System.identityHashCode;
024import static java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged;

028import static java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater.newUpdater;
029import static java.util.logging.Level.SEVERE;

031import com.google.common.annotations.GwtCompatible;
032import com.google.common.base.Strings;
033import com.google.common.util.concurrent.internal.InternalFutureFailureAccess;
034import com.google.common.util.concurrent.internal.InternalFutures;
035import com.google.errorprone.annotations.CanIgnoreReturnValue;

055/**
056 * An abstract implementation of {@link ListenableFuture}, intended for advanced users only. More
057 * common ways to create a {@code ListenableFuture} include instantiating a {@link SettableFuture},
058 * submitting a task to a {@link ListeningExecutorService}, and deriving a {@code Future} from an
059 * existing one, typically using methods like {@link Futures#transform(ListenableFuture,
060 * com.google.common.base.Function, java.util.concurrent.Executor) Futures.transform} and {@link
061 * Futures#catching(ListenableFuture, Class, com.google.common.base.Function,
062 * java.util.concurrent.Executor) Futures.catching}.
063 *
064 * <p>This class implements all methods in {@code ListenableFuture}. Subclasses should provide a way
065 * to set the result of the computation through the protected methods {@link #set(Object)}, {@link
066 * #setFuture(ListenableFuture)} and {@link #setException(Throwable)}. Subclasses may also override
067 * {@link #afterDone()}, which will be invoked automatically when the future completes. Subclasses
068 * should rarely override other methods.
069 *
070 * @author Sven Mawson
071 * @author Luke Sandberg
072 * @since 1.0
073 */
074// Whenever both tests are cheap and functional, it's faster to use &, | instead of &&, ||
075@SuppressWarnings("ShortCircuitBoolean")
076@GwtCompatible(emulated = true)
077@ReflectionSupport(value = ReflectionSupport.Level.FULL)
078public abstract class AbstractFuture<V extends @Nullable Object> extends InternalFutureFailureAccess
079    implements ListenableFuture<V> {
080  /**
081   * Performs a {@linkplain java.lang.invoke.VarHandle#compareAndSet compare-and-set} operation on
082   * the {@link #listeners} field.
083   */
084  final boolean casListeners(@Nullable Listener expect, Listener update) {
085    return ATOMIC_HELPER.casListeners(this, expect, update);
086  }
087
088  /**
089   * Performs a {@linkplain java.lang.invoke.VarHandle#getAndSet get-and-set} operation on the
090   * {@link #listeners} field..
091   */
092  final @Nullable Listener gasListeners(Listener update) {
093    return ATOMIC_HELPER.gasListeners(this, update);
094  }
095
096  /**
097   * Performs a {@linkplain java.lang.invoke.VarHandle#compareAndSet compare-and-set} operation on
098   * the {@link #value} field of {@code future}.
099   */
100  static boolean casValue(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Object expect, Object update) {
101    return ATOMIC_HELPER.casValue(future, expect, update);
102  }
103
104  /** Returns the value of the future, using a volatile read. */
105  final @Nullable Object value() {
106    return value;
107  }
108
109  /** Returns the head of the listener stack, using a volatile read. */
110  final @Nullable Listener listeners() {
111    return listeners;
112  }
113
114  /** Releases all threads in the {@link #waiters} list, and clears the list. */
115  private void releaseWaiters() {
116    Waiter head = gasWaiters(Waiter.TOMBSTONE);
117    for (Waiter currentWaiter = head; currentWaiter != null; currentWaiter = currentWaiter.next) {
118      currentWaiter.unpark();
119    }
120  }
121
122  /**
123   * Tag interface marking trusted subclasses. This enables some optimizations. The implementation
124   * of this interface must also be an AbstractFuture and must not override or expose for overriding
125   * any of the public methods of ListenableFuture.
126   */
127  interface Trusted<V extends @Nullable Object> extends ListenableFuture<V> {}
128
129  /**
130   * A less abstract subclass of AbstractFuture. This can be used to optimize setFuture by ensuring
131   * that {@link #get} calls exactly the implementation of {@link AbstractFuture#get}.
132   */
133  abstract static class TrustedFuture<V extends @Nullable Object> extends AbstractFuture<V>
134      implements Trusted<V> {
135    @CanIgnoreReturnValue
136    @Override
137    @ParametricNullness
138    public final V get() throws InterruptedException, ExecutionException {
139      return super.get();
140    }
141
142    @CanIgnoreReturnValue
143    @Override
144    @ParametricNullness
145    public final V get(long timeout, TimeUnit unit)
146        throws InterruptedException, ExecutionException, TimeoutException {
147      return super.get(timeout, unit);
148    }
149
150    @Override
151    public final boolean isDone() {
152      return super.isDone();
153    }
154
155    @Override
156    public final boolean isCancelled() {
157      return super.isCancelled();
158    }
159
160    @Override
161    public final void addListener(Runnable listener, Executor executor) {
162      super.addListener(listener, executor);
163    }
164
165    @CanIgnoreReturnValue
166    @Override
167    public final boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning) {
168      return super.cancel(mayInterruptIfRunning);
169    }
170  }
171
172  /** Listeners also form a stack through the {@link #listeners} field. */
173  private static final class Listener {
174    static final Listener TOMBSTONE = new Listener();
175    // null only for TOMBSTONE
176    final @Nullable Runnable task;
177    // null only for TOMBSTONE
178    final @Nullable Executor executor;
179
180    // writes to next are made visible by subsequent CAS's on the listeners field
181    @Nullable Listener next;
182
183    Listener(Runnable task, Executor executor) {
184      this.task = task;
185      this.executor = executor;
186    }
187
188    Listener() {
189      this.task = null;
190      this.executor = null;
191    }
192  }
193
194  /** A special value to represent failure, when {@link #setException} is called successfully. */
195  private static final class Failure {
196    static final Failure FALLBACK_INSTANCE =
197        new Failure(
198            new Throwable("Failure occurred while trying to finish a future.") {
199              @Override
200              public Throwable fillInStackTrace() {
201                return this; // no stack trace
202              }
203            });
204    final Throwable exception;
205
206    Failure(Throwable exception) {
207      this.exception = checkNotNull(exception);
208    }
209  }
210
211  /** A special value to represent cancellation and the 'wasInterrupted' bit. */
212  private static final class Cancellation {
213    // constants to use when GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES = false
214    static final @Nullable Cancellation CAUSELESS_INTERRUPTED;
215    static final @Nullable Cancellation CAUSELESS_CANCELLED;
216
217    static {
218      if (GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES) {
219        CAUSELESS_CANCELLED = null;
220        CAUSELESS_INTERRUPTED = null;
221      } else {
222        CAUSELESS_CANCELLED = new Cancellation(false, null);
223        CAUSELESS_INTERRUPTED = new Cancellation(true, null);
224      }
225    }
226
227    final boolean wasInterrupted;
228    final @Nullable Throwable cause;
229
230    Cancellation(boolean wasInterrupted, @Nullable Throwable cause) {
231      this.wasInterrupted = wasInterrupted;
232      this.cause = cause;
233    }
234  }
235
236  /** A special value that encodes the 'setFuture' state. */
237  private static final class DelegatingToFuture<V extends @Nullable Object> implements Runnable {
238    final AbstractFuture<V> owner;
239    final ListenableFuture<? extends V> future;
240
241    DelegatingToFuture(AbstractFuture<V> owner, ListenableFuture<? extends V> future) {
242      this.owner = owner;
243      this.future = future;
244    }
245
246    @Override
247    public void run() {
248      if (owner.value() != this) {
249        // nothing to do, we must have been cancelled, don't bother inspecting the future.
250        return;
251      }
252      Object valueToSet = getFutureValue(future);
253      if (casValue(owner, this, valueToSet)) {
254        complete(
255            owner,
256            /*
257             * Interruption doesn't propagate through a DelegatingToFuture chain (see
258             * getFutureValue), so don't invoke interruptTask.
259             */
260            false);
261      }
262    }
263  }
264
265  /** Constructor for use by subclasses. */
266  protected AbstractFuture() {}
267
268  // Gets and Timed Gets
269  //
270  // * Be responsive to interruption
271  // * Don't create Waiter nodes if you aren't going to park, this helps reduce contention on the
272  //   waiters field.
273  // * Future completion is defined by when #value becomes non-null/non DelegatingToFuture
274  // * Future completion can be observed if the waiters field contains a TOMBSTONE
275
276  // Timed Get
277  // There are a few design constraints to consider
278  // * We want to be responsive to small timeouts, unpark() has non trivial latency overheads (I
279  //   have observed 12 micros on 64-bit linux systems to wake up a parked thread). So if the
280  //   timeout is small we shouldn't park(). This needs to be traded off with the cpu overhead of
281  //   spinning, so we use SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS which is what AbstractQueuedSynchronizer uses for
282  //   similar purposes.
283  // * We want to behave reasonably for timeouts of 0
284  // * We are more responsive to completion than timeouts. This is because parkNanos depends on
285  //   system scheduling and as such we could either miss our deadline, or unpark() could be delayed
286  //   so that it looks like we timed out even though we didn't. For comparison FutureTask respects
287  //   completion preferably and AQS is non-deterministic (depends on where in the queue the waiter
288  //   is). If we wanted to be strict about it, we could store the unpark() time in the Waiter node
289  //   and we could use that to make a decision about whether or not we timed out prior to being
290  //   unparked.
291
292  /**
293   * {@inheritDoc}
294   *
295   * <p>The default {@link AbstractFuture} implementation throws {@code InterruptedException} if the
296   * current thread is interrupted during the call, even if the value is already available.
297   *
298   * @throws CancellationException {@inheritDoc}
299   */
300  @SuppressWarnings({
301    "LabelledBreakTarget", // TODO(b/345814817): Maybe fix?
302    "nullness", // TODO(b/147136275): Remove once our checker understands & and |.
303  })
304  @CanIgnoreReturnValue
305  @Override
306  @ParametricNullness
307  public V get(long timeout, TimeUnit unit)
308      throws InterruptedException, TimeoutException, ExecutionException {
309    // NOTE: if timeout < 0, remainingNanos will be < 0 and we will fall into the while(true) loop
310    // at the bottom and throw a timeoutexception.
311    long timeoutNanos = unit.toNanos(timeout); // we rely on the implicit null check on unit.
312    long remainingNanos = timeoutNanos;
313    if (Thread.interrupted()) {
314      throw new InterruptedException();
315    }
316    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value;
317    if (localValue != null & !(localValue instanceof DelegatingToFuture)) {
318      return getDoneValue(localValue);
319    }
320    // we delay calling nanoTime until we know we will need to either park or spin
321    long endNanos = remainingNanos > 0 ? System.nanoTime() + remainingNanos : 0;
322    long_wait_loop:
323    if (remainingNanos >= SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS) {
324      Waiter oldHead = waiters;
325      if (oldHead != Waiter.TOMBSTONE) {
326        Waiter node = new Waiter();
327        do {
328          node.setNext(oldHead);
329          if (casWaiters(oldHead, node)) {
330            while (true) {
331              OverflowAvoidingLockSupport.parkNanos(this, remainingNanos);
332              // Check interruption first, if we woke up due to interruption we need to honor that.
333              if (Thread.interrupted()) {
334                removeWaiter(node);
335                throw new InterruptedException();
336              }
337
338              // Otherwise re-read and check doneness. If we loop then it must have been a spurious
339              // wakeup
340              localValue = value;
341              if (localValue != null & !(localValue instanceof DelegatingToFuture)) {
342                return getDoneValue(localValue);
343              }
344
345              // timed out?
346              remainingNanos = endNanos - System.nanoTime();
347              if (remainingNanos < SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS) {
348                // Remove the waiter, one way or another we are done parking this thread.
349                removeWaiter(node);
350                break long_wait_loop; // jump down to the busy wait loop
351              }
352            }
353          }
354          oldHead = waiters; // re-read and loop.
355        } while (oldHead != Waiter.TOMBSTONE);
356      }
357      // re-read value, if we get here then we must have observed a TOMBSTONE while trying to add a
358      // waiter.
359      // requireNonNull is safe because value is always set before TOMBSTONE.
360      return getDoneValue(requireNonNull(value));
361    }
362    // If we get here then we have remainingNanos < SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS and there is no node on the
363    // waiters list
364    while (remainingNanos > 0) {
365      localValue = value;
366      if (localValue != null & !(localValue instanceof DelegatingToFuture)) {
367        return getDoneValue(localValue);
368      }
369      if (Thread.interrupted()) {
370        throw new InterruptedException();
371      }
372      remainingNanos = endNanos - System.nanoTime();
373    }
374
375    String futureToString = toString();
376    String unitString = unit.toString().toLowerCase(Locale.ROOT);
377    String message = "Waited " + timeout + " " + unit.toString().toLowerCase(Locale.ROOT);
378    // Only report scheduling delay if larger than our spin threshold - otherwise it's just noise
379    if (remainingNanos + SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS < 0) {
380      // We over-waited for our timeout.
381      message += " (plus ";
382      long overWaitNanos = -remainingNanos;
383      long overWaitUnits = unit.convert(overWaitNanos, NANOSECONDS);
384      long overWaitLeftoverNanos = overWaitNanos - unit.toNanos(overWaitUnits);
385      boolean shouldShowExtraNanos =
386          overWaitUnits == 0 || overWaitLeftoverNanos > SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS;
387      if (overWaitUnits > 0) {
388        message += overWaitUnits + " " + unitString;
389        if (shouldShowExtraNanos) {
390          message += ",";
391        }
392        message += " ";
393      }
394      if (shouldShowExtraNanos) {
395        message += overWaitLeftoverNanos + " nanoseconds ";
396      }
397
398      message += "delay)";
399    }
400    // It's confusing to see a completed future in a timeout message; if isDone() returns false,
401    // then we know it must have given a pending toString value earlier. If not, then the future
402    // completed after the timeout expired, and the message might be success.
403    if (isDone()) {
404      throw new TimeoutException(message + " but future completed as timeout expired");
405    }
406    throw new TimeoutException(message + " for " + futureToString);
407  }
408
409  /**
410   * {@inheritDoc}
411   *
412   * <p>The default {@link AbstractFuture} implementation throws {@code InterruptedException} if the
413   * current thread is interrupted during the call, even if the value is already available.
414   *
415   * @throws CancellationException {@inheritDoc}
416   */
417  @CanIgnoreReturnValue
418  @Override
419  @ParametricNullness
420  @SuppressWarnings("nullness") // TODO(b/147136275): Remove once our checker understands & and |.
421  public V get() throws InterruptedException, ExecutionException {
422    if (Thread.interrupted()) {
423      throw new InterruptedException();
424    }
425    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value;
426    if (localValue != null & !(localValue instanceof DelegatingToFuture)) {
427      return getDoneValue(localValue);
428    }
429    Waiter oldHead = waiters;
430    if (oldHead != Waiter.TOMBSTONE) {
431      Waiter node = new Waiter();
432      do {
433        node.setNext(oldHead);
434        if (casWaiters(oldHead, node)) {
435          // we are on the stack, now wait for completion.
436          while (true) {
437            LockSupport.park(this);
438            // Check interruption first, if we woke up due to interruption we need to honor that.
439            if (Thread.interrupted()) {
440              removeWaiter(node);
441              throw new InterruptedException();
442            }
443            // Otherwise re-read and check doneness. If we loop then it must have been a spurious
444            // wakeup
445            localValue = value;
446            if (localValue != null & !(localValue instanceof DelegatingToFuture)) {
447              return getDoneValue(localValue);
448            }
449          }
450        }
451        oldHead = waiters; // re-read and loop.
452      } while (oldHead != Waiter.TOMBSTONE);
453    }
454    // re-read value, if we get here then we must have observed a TOMBSTONE while trying to add a
455    // waiter.
456    // requireNonNull is safe because value is always set before TOMBSTONE.
457    return getDoneValue(requireNonNull(value));
458  }
459
460  /** A special value to represent {@code null}. */
461  private static final Object NULL = new Object();
462
463  static final LazyLogger log = new LazyLogger(AbstractFuture.class);
464
465  static final boolean GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES;
466
467  static {
468    // System.getProperty may throw if the security policy does not permit access.
469    boolean generateCancellationCauses;
470    try {
471      generateCancellationCauses =
472          parseBoolean(System.getProperty("guava.concurrent.generate_cancellation_cause", "false"));
473    } catch (SecurityException e) {
474      generateCancellationCauses = false;
475    }
476    GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES = generateCancellationCauses;
477  }
478
479  /** Waiter links form a Treiber stack, in the {@link #waiters} field. */
480  private static final class Waiter {
481    static final Waiter TOMBSTONE = new Waiter(false /* ignored param */);
482
483    volatile @Nullable Thread thread;
484    volatile @Nullable Waiter next;
485
486    /**
487     * Constructor for the TOMBSTONE, avoids use of ATOMIC_HELPER in case this class is loaded
488     * before the ATOMIC_HELPER. Apparently this is possible on some android platforms.
489     */
490    Waiter(boolean unused) {}
491
492    Waiter() {
493      // avoid volatile write, write is made visible by subsequent CAS on waiters field
494      putThread(this, Thread.currentThread());
495    }
496
497    // non-volatile write to the next field. Should be made visible by subsequent CAS on waiters
498    // field.
499    void setNext(@Nullable Waiter next) {
500      putNext(this, next);
501    }
502
503    void unpark() {
504      // This is racy with removeWaiter. The consequence of the race is that we may spuriously call
505      // unpark even though the thread has already removed itself from the list. But even if we did
506      // use a CAS, that race would still exist (it would just be ever so slightly smaller).
507      Thread w = thread;
508      if (w != null) {
509        thread = null;
510        LockSupport.unpark(w);
511      }
512    }
513  }
514
515  /*
516   * Now that we've initialized everything else, we can run the initialization code for
517   * ATOMIC_HELPER. That initialization code may log after we assign to ATOMIC_HELPER.
518   */
519
520  private static final AtomicHelper ATOMIC_HELPER;
521
522  static {
523    AtomicHelper helper;
524    Throwable thrownUnsafeFailure = null;
525    Throwable thrownAtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterFailure = null;
526
527    try {
528      helper = new UnsafeAtomicHelper();
529    } catch (Exception | Error unsafeFailure) { // sneaky checked exception
530      thrownUnsafeFailure = unsafeFailure;
531      // Catch absolutely everything and fall through to AtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterAtomicHelper.
532      try {
533        helper = new AtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterAtomicHelper();
534      } catch (Exception // sneaky checked exception
535          | Error atomicReferenceFieldUpdaterFailure) {
536        // Some Android 5.0.x Samsung devices have bugs in JDK reflection APIs that cause
537        // getDeclaredField to throw a NoSuchFieldException when the field is definitely there.
538        // For these users fallback to a suboptimal implementation, based on synchronized. This
539        // will be a definite performance hit to those users.
540        thrownAtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterFailure = atomicReferenceFieldUpdaterFailure;
541        helper = new SynchronizedHelper();
542      }
543    }
544    ATOMIC_HELPER = helper;
545
546    // Prevent rare disastrous classloading in first call to LockSupport.park.
547    // See: https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8074773
548    @SuppressWarnings("unused")
549    Class<?> ensureLoaded = LockSupport.class;
550
551    // Log after all static init is finished; if an installed logger uses any Futures methods, it
552    // shouldn't break in cases where reflection is missing/broken.
553    if (thrownAtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterFailure != null) {
554      log.get().log(SEVERE, "UnsafeAtomicHelper is broken!", thrownUnsafeFailure);
555      log.get()
556          .log(
557              SEVERE,
558              "AtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterAtomicHelper is broken!",
559              thrownAtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterFailure);
560    }
561  }
562
563  // TODO(lukes): investigate using the @Contended annotation on these fields when jdk8 is
564  // available.
565  /**
566   * This field encodes the current state of the future.
567   *
568   * <p>The valid values are:
569   *
570   * <ul>
571   *   <li>{@code null} initial state, nothing has happened.
572   *   <li>{@link Cancellation} terminal state, {@code cancel} was called.
573   *   <li>{@link Failure} terminal state, {@code setException} was called.
574   *   <li>{@link DelegatingToFuture} intermediate state, {@code setFuture} was called.
575   *   <li>{@link #NULL} terminal state, {@code set(null)} was called.
576   *   <li>Any other non-null value, terminal state, {@code set} was called with a non-null
577   *       argument.
578   * </ul>
579   */
580  private volatile @Nullable Object value;
581
582  /** All listeners. */
583  private volatile @Nullable Listener listeners;
584
585  /** All waiting threads. */
586  private volatile @Nullable Waiter waiters;
587
588  /** Non-volatile write of the thread to the {@link Waiter#thread} field. */
589  private static void putThread(Waiter waiter, Thread newValue) {
590    ATOMIC_HELPER.putThread(waiter, newValue);
591  }
592
593  /** Non-volatile write of the waiter to the {@link Waiter#next} field. */
594  private static void putNext(Waiter waiter, @Nullable Waiter newValue) {
595    ATOMIC_HELPER.putNext(waiter, newValue);
596  }
597
598  /**
599   * Performs a {@linkplain java.lang.invoke.VarHandle#compareAndSet compare-and-set} operation on
600   * the {@link #waiters} field.
601   */
602  private boolean casWaiters(@Nullable Waiter expect, @Nullable Waiter update) {
603    return ATOMIC_HELPER.casWaiters(this, expect, update);
604  }
605
606  /**
607   * Performs a {@linkplain java.lang.invoke.VarHandle#getAndSet get-and-set} operation on the
608   * {@link #waiters} field.
609   */
610  private final @Nullable Waiter gasWaiters(Waiter update) {
611    return ATOMIC_HELPER.gasWaiters(this, update);
612  }
613
614  /**
615   * Marks the given node as 'deleted' (null waiter) and then scans the list to unlink all deleted
616   * nodes. This is an O(n) operation in the common case (and O(n^2) in the worst), but we are saved
617   * by two things.
618   *
619   * <ul>
620   *   <li>This is only called when a waiting thread times out or is interrupted. Both of which
621   *       should be rare.
622   *   <li>The waiters list should be very short.
623   * </ul>
624   */
625  private void removeWaiter(Waiter node) {
626    node.thread = null; // mark as 'deleted'
627    restart:
628    while (true) {
629      Waiter pred = null;
630      Waiter curr = waiters;
631      if (curr == Waiter.TOMBSTONE) {
632        return; // give up if someone is calling complete
633      }
634      Waiter succ;
635      while (curr != null) {
636        succ = curr.next;
637        if (curr.thread != null) { // we aren't unlinking this node, update pred.
638          pred = curr;
639        } else if (pred != null) { // We are unlinking this node and it has a predecessor.
640          pred.next = succ;
641          if (pred.thread == null) { // We raced with another node that unlinked pred. Restart.
642            continue restart;
643          }
644        } else if (!casWaiters(curr, succ)) { // We are unlinking head
645          continue restart; // We raced with an add or complete
646        }
647        curr = succ;
648      }
649      break;
650    }
651  }
652
653  // A heuristic for timed gets. If the remaining timeout is less than this, spin instead of
654  // blocking. This value is what AbstractQueuedSynchronizer uses.
655  private static final long SPIN_THRESHOLD_NANOS = 1000L;
656
657  /** Unboxes {@code obj}. Assumes that obj is not {@code null} or a {@link DelegatingToFuture}. */
658  @ParametricNullness
659  @SuppressWarnings("TypeParameterUnusedInFormals") // sorry not sorry
660  static <V extends @Nullable Object> V getDoneValue(Object obj) throws ExecutionException {
661    // While this seems like it might be too branch-y, simple benchmarking proves it to be
662    // unmeasurable (comparing done AbstractFutures with immediateFuture)
663    if (obj instanceof Cancellation) {
664      Cancellation cancellation = (Cancellation) obj;
665      Throwable cause = cancellation.cause;
666      throw cancellationExceptionWithCause("Task was cancelled.", cause);
667    } else if (obj instanceof Failure) {
668      Failure failure = (Failure) obj;
669      Throwable exception = failure.exception;
670      throw new ExecutionException(exception);
671    } else if (obj == NULL) {
672      /*
673       * It's safe to return null because we would only have stored it in the first place if it were
674       * a valid value for V.
675       */
676      return uncheckedNull();
677    } else {
678      @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") // this is the only other option
679      V asV = (V) obj;
680      return asV;
681    }
682  }
683
684  @Override
685  public boolean isDone() {
686    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value();
687    return localValue != null & !(localValue instanceof DelegatingToFuture);
688  }
689
690  @Override
691  public boolean isCancelled() {
692    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value();
693    return localValue instanceof Cancellation;
694  }
695
696  /**
697   * {@inheritDoc}
698   *
699   * <p>If a cancellation attempt succeeds on a {@code Future} that had previously been {@linkplain
700   * #setFuture set asynchronously}, then the cancellation will also be propagated to the delegate
701   * {@code Future} that was supplied in the {@code setFuture} call.
702   *
703   * <p>Rather than override this method to perform additional cancellation work or cleanup,
704   * subclasses should override {@link #afterDone}, consulting {@link #isCancelled} and {@link
705   * #wasInterrupted} as necessary. This ensures that the work is done even if the future is
706   * cancelled without a call to {@code cancel}, such as by calling {@code
707   * setFuture(cancelledFuture)}.
708   *
709   * <p>Beware of completing a future while holding a lock. Its listeners may do slow work or
710   * acquire other locks, risking deadlocks.
711   */
712  @CanIgnoreReturnValue
713  @Override
714  public boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning) {
715    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value();
716    boolean rValue = false;
717    if (localValue == null | localValue instanceof DelegatingToFuture) {
718      // Try to delay allocating the exception. At this point we may still lose the CAS, but it is
719      // certainly less likely.
720      Object valueToSet =
721          GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES
722              ? new Cancellation(
723                  mayInterruptIfRunning, new CancellationException("Future.cancel() was called."))
724              /*
725               * requireNonNull is safe because we've initialized these if
726               * !GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES.
727               *
728               * TODO(cpovirk): Maybe it would be cleaner to define a CancellationSupplier interface
729               * with two implementations, one that contains causeless Cancellation instances and
730               * the other of which creates new Cancellation instances each time it's called? Yet
731               * another alternative is to fill in a non-null value for each of the fields no matter
732               * what and to just not use it if !GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES.
733               */
734              : requireNonNull(
735                  mayInterruptIfRunning
736                      ? Cancellation.CAUSELESS_INTERRUPTED
737                      : Cancellation.CAUSELESS_CANCELLED);
738      AbstractFuture<?> abstractFuture = this;
739      while (true) {
740        if (casValue(abstractFuture, localValue, valueToSet)) {
741          rValue = true;
742          complete(abstractFuture, mayInterruptIfRunning);
743          if (localValue instanceof DelegatingToFuture) {
744            // propagate cancellation to the future set in setfuture, this is racy, and we don't
745            // care if we are successful or not.
746            ListenableFuture<?> futureToPropagateTo = ((DelegatingToFuture) localValue).future;
747            if (futureToPropagateTo instanceof Trusted) {
748              // If the future is a TrustedFuture then we specifically avoid calling cancel()
749              // this has 2 benefits
750              // 1. for long chains of futures strung together with setFuture we consume less stack
751              // 2. we avoid allocating Cancellation objects at every level of the cancellation
752              //    chain
753              // We can only do this for TrustedFuture, because TrustedFuture.cancel is final and
754              // does nothing but delegate to this method.
755              AbstractFuture<?> trusted = (AbstractFuture<?>) futureToPropagateTo;
756              localValue = trusted.value();
757              if (localValue == null | localValue instanceof DelegatingToFuture) {
758                abstractFuture = trusted;
759                continue; // loop back up and try to complete the new future
760              }
761            } else {
762              // not a TrustedFuture, call cancel directly.
763              futureToPropagateTo.cancel(mayInterruptIfRunning);
764            }
765          }
766          break;
767        }
768        // obj changed, reread
769        localValue = abstractFuture.value();
770        if (!(localValue instanceof DelegatingToFuture)) {
771          // obj cannot be null at this point, because value can only change from null to non-null.
772          // So if value changed (and it did since we lost the CAS), then it cannot be null and
773          // since it isn't a DelegatingToFuture, then the future must be done and we should exit
774          // the loop
775          break;
776        }
777      }
778    }
779    return rValue;
780  }
781
782  /**
783   * Subclasses can override this method to implement interruption of the future's computation. The
784   * method is invoked automatically by a successful call to {@link #cancel(boolean) cancel(true)}.
785   *
786   * <p>The default implementation does nothing.
787   *
788   * <p>This method is likely to be deprecated. Prefer to override {@link #afterDone}, checking
789   * {@link #wasInterrupted} to decide whether to interrupt your task.
790   *
791   * @since 10.0
792   */
793  protected void interruptTask() {}
794
795  /**
796   * Returns true if this future was cancelled with {@code mayInterruptIfRunning} set to {@code
797   * true}.
798   *
799   * @since 14.0
800   */
801  protected final boolean wasInterrupted() {
802    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value();
803    return (localValue instanceof Cancellation) && ((Cancellation) localValue).wasInterrupted;
804  }
805
806  /**
807   * {@inheritDoc}
808   *
809   * @since 10.0
810   */
811  @Override
812  public void addListener(Runnable listener, Executor executor) {
813    checkNotNull(listener, "Runnable was null.");
814    checkNotNull(executor, "Executor was null.");
815    // Checking isDone and listeners != TOMBSTONE may seem redundant, but our contract for
816    // addListener says that listeners execute 'immediate' if the future isDone(). However, our
817    // protocol for completing a future is to assign the value field (which sets isDone to true) and
818    // then to release waiters, followed by executing afterDone(), followed by releasing listeners.
819    // That means that it is possible to observe that the future isDone and that your listeners
820    // don't execute 'immediately'.  By checking isDone here we avoid that.
821    // A corollary to all that is that we don't need to check isDone inside the loop because if we
822    // get into the loop we know that we weren't done when we entered and therefore we aren't under
823    // an obligation to execute 'immediately'.
824    if (!isDone()) {
825      Listener oldHead = listeners();
826      if (oldHead != Listener.TOMBSTONE) {
827        Listener newNode = new Listener(listener, executor);
828        do {
829          newNode.next = oldHead;
830          if (casListeners(oldHead, newNode)) {
831            return;
832          }
833          oldHead = listeners(); // re-read
834        } while (oldHead != Listener.TOMBSTONE);
835      }
836    }
837    // If we get here then the Listener TOMBSTONE was set, which means the future is done, call
838    // the listener.
839    executeListener(listener, executor);
840  }
841
842  /**
843   * Sets the result of this {@code Future} unless this {@code Future} has already been cancelled or
844   * set (including {@linkplain #setFuture set asynchronously}). When a call to this method returns,
845   * the {@code Future} is guaranteed to be {@linkplain #isDone done} <b>only if</b> the call was
846   * accepted (in which case it returns {@code true}). If it returns {@code false}, the {@code
847   * Future} may have previously been set asynchronously, in which case its result may not be known
848   * yet. That result, though not yet known, cannot be overridden by a call to a {@code set*}
849   * method, only by a call to {@link #cancel}.
850   *
851   * <p>Beware of completing a future while holding a lock. Its listeners may do slow work or
852   * acquire other locks, risking deadlocks.
853   *
854   * @param value the value to be used as the result
855   * @return true if the attempt was accepted, completing the {@code Future}
856   */
857  @CanIgnoreReturnValue
858  protected boolean set(@ParametricNullness V value) {
859    Object valueToSet = value == null ? NULL : value;
860    if (casValue(this, null, valueToSet)) {
861      complete(this, /* callInterruptTask= */ false);
862      return true;
863    }
864    return false;
865  }
866
867  /**
868   * Sets the failed result of this {@code Future} unless this {@code Future} has already been
869   * cancelled or set (including {@linkplain #setFuture set asynchronously}). When a call to this
870   * method returns, the {@code Future} is guaranteed to be {@linkplain #isDone done} <b>only if</b>
871   * the call was accepted (in which case it returns {@code true}). If it returns {@code false}, the
872   * {@code Future} may have previously been set asynchronously, in which case its result may not be
873   * known yet. That result, though not yet known, cannot be overridden by a call to a {@code set*}
874   * method, only by a call to {@link #cancel}.
875   *
876   * <p>Beware of completing a future while holding a lock. Its listeners may do slow work or
877   * acquire other locks, risking deadlocks.
878   *
879   * @param throwable the exception to be used as the failed result
880   * @return true if the attempt was accepted, completing the {@code Future}
881   */
882  @CanIgnoreReturnValue
883  protected boolean setException(Throwable throwable) {
884    Object valueToSet = new Failure(checkNotNull(throwable));
885    if (casValue(this, null, valueToSet)) {
886      complete(this, /* callInterruptTask= */ false);
887      return true;
888    }
889    return false;
890  }
891
892  /**
893   * Sets the result of this {@code Future} to match the supplied input {@code Future} once the
894   * supplied {@code Future} is done, unless this {@code Future} has already been cancelled or set
895   * (including "set asynchronously," defined below).
896   *
897   * <p>If the supplied future is {@linkplain #isDone done} when this method is called and the call
898   * is accepted, then this future is guaranteed to have been completed with the supplied future by
899   * the time this method returns. If the supplied future is not done and the call is accepted, then
900   * the future will be <i>set asynchronously</i>. Note that such a result, though not yet known,
901   * cannot be overridden by a call to a {@code set*} method, only by a call to {@link #cancel}.
902   *
903   * <p>If the call {@code setFuture(delegate)} is accepted and this {@code Future} is later
904   * cancelled, cancellation will be propagated to {@code delegate}. Additionally, any call to
905   * {@code setFuture} after any cancellation will propagate cancellation to the supplied {@code
906   * Future}.
907   *
908   * <p>Note that, even if the supplied future is cancelled and it causes this future to complete,
909   * it will never trigger interruption behavior. In particular, it will not cause this future to
910   * invoke the {@link #interruptTask} method, and the {@link #wasInterrupted} method will not
911   * return {@code true}.
912   *
913   * <p>Beware of completing a future while holding a lock. Its listeners may do slow work or
914   * acquire other locks, risking deadlocks.
915   *
916   * @param future the future to delegate to
917   * @return true if the attempt was accepted, indicating that the {@code Future} was not previously
918   *     cancelled or set.
919   * @since 19.0
920   */
921  @CanIgnoreReturnValue
922  @SuppressWarnings("Interruption") // We are propagating an interrupt from a caller.
923  protected boolean setFuture(ListenableFuture<? extends V> future) {
924    checkNotNull(future);
925    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value();
926    if (localValue == null) {
927      if (future.isDone()) {
928        Object value = getFutureValue(future);
929        if (casValue(this, null, value)) {
930          complete(
931              this,
932              /*
933               * Interruption doesn't propagate through a DelegatingToFuture chain (see
934               * getFutureValue), so don't invoke interruptTask.
935               */
936              false);
937          return true;
938        }
939        return false;
940      }
941      DelegatingToFuture<V> valueToSet = new DelegatingToFuture<>(this, future);
942      if (casValue(this, null, valueToSet)) {
943        // the listener is responsible for calling completeWithFuture, directExecutor is appropriate
944        // since all we are doing is unpacking a completed future which should be fast.
945        try {
946          future.addListener(valueToSet, DirectExecutor.INSTANCE);
947        } catch (Throwable t) {
948          // Any Exception is either a RuntimeException or sneaky checked exception.
949          //
950          // addListener has thrown an exception! DelegatingToFuture.run can't throw any exceptions
951          // so this must have been caused by addListener itself. The most likely explanation is a
952          // misconfigured mock. Try to switch to Failure.
953          Failure failure;
954          try {
955            failure = new Failure(t);
956          } catch (Exception | Error oomMostLikely) { // sneaky checked exception
957            failure = Failure.FALLBACK_INSTANCE;
958          }
959          // Note: The only way this CAS could fail is if cancel() has raced with us. That is ok.
960          boolean unused = casValue(this, valueToSet, failure);
961        }
962        return true;
963      }
964      localValue = value(); // we lost the cas, fall through and maybe cancel
965    }
966    // The future has already been set to something. If it is cancellation we should cancel the
967    // incoming future.
968    if (localValue instanceof Cancellation) {
969      // we don't care if it fails, this is best-effort.
970      future.cancel(((Cancellation) localValue).wasInterrupted);
971    }
972    return false;
973  }
974
975  /**
976   * Returns a value that satisfies the contract of the {@link #value} field based on the state of
977   * given future.
978   *
979   * <p>This is approximately the inverse of {@link #getDoneValue(Object)}
980   */
981  private static Object getFutureValue(ListenableFuture<?> future) {
982    if (future instanceof Trusted) {
983      // Break encapsulation for TrustedFuture instances since we know that subclasses cannot
984      // override .get() (since it is final) and therefore this is equivalent to calling .get()
985      // and unpacking the exceptions like we do below (just much faster because it is a single
986      // field read instead of a read, several branches and possibly creating exceptions).
987      Object v = ((AbstractFuture<?>) future).value();
988      if (v instanceof Cancellation) {
989        // If the other future was interrupted, clear the interrupted bit while preserving the cause
990        // this will make it consistent with how non-trustedfutures work which cannot propagate the
991        // wasInterrupted bit
992        Cancellation c = (Cancellation) v;
993        if (c.wasInterrupted) {
994          v =
995              c.cause != null
996                  ? new Cancellation(/* wasInterrupted= */ false, c.cause)
997                  : Cancellation.CAUSELESS_CANCELLED;
998        }
999      }
1000      // requireNonNull is safe as long as we call this method only on completed futures.
1001      return requireNonNull(v);
1002    }
1003    if (future instanceof InternalFutureFailureAccess) {
1004      Throwable throwable =
1005          InternalFutures.tryInternalFastPathGetFailure((InternalFutureFailureAccess) future);
1006      if (throwable != null) {
1007        return new Failure(throwable);
1008      }
1009    }
1010    boolean wasCancelled = future.isCancelled();
1011    // Don't allocate a CancellationException if it's not necessary
1012    if (!GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES & wasCancelled) {
1013      /*
1014       * requireNonNull is safe because we've initialized CAUSELESS_CANCELLED if
1015       * !GENERATE_CANCELLATION_CAUSES.
1016       */
1017      return requireNonNull(Cancellation.CAUSELESS_CANCELLED);
1018    }
1019    // Otherwise calculate the value by calling .get()
1020    try {
1021      Object v = getUninterruptibly(future);
1022      if (wasCancelled) {
1023        return new Cancellation(
1024            false,
1025            new IllegalArgumentException(
1026                "get() did not throw CancellationException, despite reporting "
1027                    + "isCancelled() == true: "
1028                    + future));
1029      }
1030      return v == null ? NULL : v;
1031    } catch (ExecutionException exception) {
1032      if (wasCancelled) {
1033        return new Cancellation(
1034            false,
1035            new IllegalArgumentException(
1036                "get() did not throw CancellationException, despite reporting "
1037                    + "isCancelled() == true: "
1038                    + future,
1039                exception));
1040      }
1041      return new Failure(exception.getCause());
1042    } catch (CancellationException cancellation) {
1043      if (!wasCancelled) {
1044        return new Failure(
1045            new IllegalArgumentException(
1046                "get() threw CancellationException, despite reporting isCancelled() == false: "
1047                    + future,
1048                cancellation));
1049      }
1050      return new Cancellation(false, cancellation);
1051    } catch (Exception | Error t) { // sneaky checked exception
1052      return new Failure(t);
1053    }
1054  }
1055
1056  /**
1057   * An inlined private copy of {@link Uninterruptibles#getUninterruptibly} used to break an
1058   * internal dependency on other /util/concurrent classes.
1059   */
1060  @ParametricNullness
1061  private static <V extends @Nullable Object> V getUninterruptibly(Future<V> future)
1062      throws ExecutionException {
1063    boolean interrupted = false;
1064    try {
1065      while (true) {
1066        try {
1067          return future.get();
1068        } catch (InterruptedException e) {
1069          interrupted = true;
1070        }
1071      }
1072    } finally {
1073      if (interrupted) {
1074        interruptCurrentThread();
1075      }
1076    }
1077  }
1078
1079  /** Unblocks all threads and runs all listeners. */
1080  private static void complete(AbstractFuture<?> param, boolean callInterruptTask) {
1081    // Declare a "true" local variable so that the Checker Framework will infer nullness.
1082    AbstractFuture<?> future = param;
1083
1084    Listener next = null;
1085    outer:
1086    while (true) {
1087      future.releaseWaiters();
1088      /*
1089       * We call interruptTask() immediately before afterDone() so that migrating between the two
1090       * can be a no-op.
1091       */
1092      if (callInterruptTask) {
1093        future.interruptTask();
1094        /*
1095         * Interruption doesn't propagate through a DelegatingToFuture chain (see getFutureValue),
1096         * so don't invoke interruptTask on any subsequent futures.
1097         */
1098        callInterruptTask = false;
1099      }
1100      // We call this before the listeners in order to avoid needing to manage a separate stack data
1101      // structure for them.  Also, some implementations rely on this running prior to listeners
1102      // so that the cleanup work is visible to listeners.
1103      // afterDone() should be generally fast and only used for cleanup work... but in theory can
1104      // also be recursive and create StackOverflowErrors
1105      future.afterDone();
1106      // push the current set of listeners onto next
1107      next = future.clearListeners(next);
1108      future = null;
1109      while (next != null) {
1110        Listener curr = next;
1111        next = next.next;
1112        /*
1113         * requireNonNull is safe because the listener stack never contains TOMBSTONE until after
1114         * clearListeners.
1115         */
1116        Runnable task = requireNonNull(curr.task);
1117        if (task instanceof DelegatingToFuture) {
1118          DelegatingToFuture<?> setFuture = (DelegatingToFuture<?>) task;
1119          // We unwind setFuture specifically to avoid StackOverflowErrors in the case of long
1120          // chains of DelegatingToFutures
1121          // Handling this special case is important because there is no way to pass an executor to
1122          // setFuture, so a user couldn't break the chain by doing this themselves.  It is also
1123          // potentially common if someone writes a recursive Futures.transformAsync transformer.
1124          future = setFuture.owner;
1125          if (future.value() == setFuture) {
1126            Object valueToSet = getFutureValue(setFuture.future);
1127            if (casValue(future, setFuture, valueToSet)) {
1128              continue outer;
1129            }
1130          }
1131          // otherwise the future we were trying to set is already done.
1132        } else {
1133          /*
1134           * requireNonNull is safe because the listener stack never contains TOMBSTONE until after
1135           * clearListeners.
1136           */
1137          executeListener(task, requireNonNull(curr.executor));
1138        }
1139      }
1140      break;
1141    }
1142  }
1143
1144  /**
1145   * Callback method that is called exactly once after the future is completed.
1146   *
1147   * <p>If {@link #interruptTask} is also run during completion, {@link #afterDone} runs after it.
1148   *
1149   * <p>The default implementation of this method in {@code AbstractFuture} does nothing. This is
1150   * intended for very lightweight cleanup work, for example, timing statistics or clearing fields.
1151   * If your task does anything heavier consider, just using a listener with an executor.
1152   *
1153   * @since 20.0
1154   */
1155  @ForOverride
1156  protected void afterDone() {}
1157
1158  // TODO(b/114236866): Inherit doc from InternalFutureFailureAccess. Also, -link to its URL.
1159  /**
1160   * Usually returns {@code null} but, if this {@code Future} has failed, may <i>optionally</i>
1161   * return the cause of the failure. "Failure" means specifically "completed with an exception"; it
1162   * does not include "was cancelled." To be explicit: If this method returns a non-null value,
1163   * then:
1164   *
1165   * <ul>
1166   *   <li>{@code isDone()} must return {@code true}
1167   *   <li>{@code isCancelled()} must return {@code false}
1168   *   <li>{@code get()} must not block, and it must throw an {@code ExecutionException} with the
1169   *       return value of this method as its cause
1170   * </ul>
1171   *
1172   * <p>This method is {@code protected} so that classes like {@code
1173   * com.google.common.util.concurrent.SettableFuture} do not expose it to their users as an
1174   * instance method. In the unlikely event that you need to call this method, call {@link
1175   * InternalFutures#tryInternalFastPathGetFailure(InternalFutureFailureAccess)}.
1176   *
1177   * @since 27.0
1178   */
1179  @Override
1180  /*
1181   * We should annotate the superclass, InternalFutureFailureAccess, to say that its copy of this
1182   * method returns @Nullable, too. However, we're not sure if we want to make any changes to that
1183   * class, since it's in a separate artifact that we planned to release only a single version of.
1184   */
1185  protected final @Nullable Throwable tryInternalFastPathGetFailure() {
1186    if (this instanceof Trusted) {
1187      @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value();
1188      if (localValue instanceof Failure) {
1189        return ((Failure) localValue).exception;
1190      }
1191    }
1192    return null;
1193  }
1194
1195  /**
1196   * If this future has been cancelled (and possibly interrupted), cancels (and possibly interrupts)
1197   * the given future (if available).
1198   */
1199  @SuppressWarnings("nullness") // TODO(b/147136275): Remove once our checker understands & and |.
1200  final void maybePropagateCancellationTo(@Nullable Future<?> related) {
1201    if (related != null & isCancelled()) {
1202      related.cancel(wasInterrupted());
1203    }
1204  }
1205
1206  /**
1207   * Clears the {@link #listeners} list and prepends its contents to {@code onto}, least recently
1208   * added first.
1209   */
1210  private @Nullable Listener clearListeners(@Nullable Listener onto) {
1211    // We need to
1212    // 1. atomically swap the listeners with TOMBSTONE, this is because addListener uses that
1213    //    to synchronize with us
1214    // 2. reverse the linked list, because despite our rather clear contract, people depend on us
1215    //    executing listeners in the order they were added
1216    // 3. push all the items onto 'onto' and return the new head of the stack
1217    Listener head = gasListeners(Listener.TOMBSTONE);
1218    Listener reversedList = onto;
1219    while (head != null) {
1220      Listener tmp = head;
1221      head = head.next;
1222      tmp.next = reversedList;
1223      reversedList = tmp;
1224    }
1225    return reversedList;
1226  }
1227
1228  // TODO(user): move parts into a default method on ListenableFuture?
1229  @Override
1230  public String toString() {
1231    // TODO(cpovirk): Presize to something plausible?
1232    StringBuilder builder = new StringBuilder();
1233    if (getClass().getName().startsWith("com.google.common.util.concurrent.")) {
1234      builder.append(getClass().getSimpleName());
1235    } else {
1236      builder.append(getClass().getName());
1237    }
1238    builder.append('@').append(toHexString(identityHashCode(this))).append("[status=");
1239    if (isCancelled()) {
1240      builder.append("CANCELLED");
1241    } else if (isDone()) {
1242      addDoneString(builder);
1243    } else {
1244      addPendingString(builder); // delegates to addDoneString if future completes midway
1245    }
1246    return builder.append("]").toString();
1247  }
1248
1249  /**
1250   * Provide a human-readable explanation of why this future has not yet completed.
1251   *
1252   * @return null if an explanation cannot be provided (e.g. because the future is done).
1253   * @since 23.0
1254   */
1255  protected @Nullable String pendingToString() {
1256    // TODO(diamondm) consider moving this into addPendingString so it's always in the output
1257    if (this instanceof ScheduledFuture) {
1258      return "remaining delay=[" + ((ScheduledFuture) this).getDelay(MILLISECONDS) + " ms]";
1259    }
1260    return null;
1261  }
1262
1263  @SuppressWarnings("CatchingUnchecked") // sneaky checked exception
1264  private void addPendingString(StringBuilder builder) {
1265    // Capture current builder length so it can be truncated if this future ends up completing while
1266    // the toString is being calculated
1267    int truncateLength = builder.length();
1268
1269    builder.append("PENDING");
1270
1271    @RetainedLocalRef Object localValue = value();
1272    if (localValue instanceof DelegatingToFuture) {
1273      builder.append(", setFuture=[");
1274      appendUserObject(builder, ((DelegatingToFuture) localValue).future);
1275      builder.append("]");
1276    } else {
1277      String pendingDescription;
1278      try {
1279        pendingDescription = Strings.emptyToNull(pendingToString());
1280      } catch (Throwable e) {
1281        /*
1282         * We want to catch (Exception | StackOverflowError), but we can't under environments where
1283         * StackOverflowError doesn't exist.
1284         */
1285        rethrowIfErrorOtherThanStackOverflow(e);
1286        // The Throwable is either a RuntimeException, an Error, or sneaky checked exception.
1287        //
1288        // Don't call getMessage or toString() on the exception, in case the exception thrown by the
1289        // subclass is implemented with bugs similar to the subclass.
1290        pendingDescription = "Exception thrown from implementation: " + e.getClass();
1291      }
1292      if (pendingDescription != null) {
1293        builder.append(", info=[").append(pendingDescription).append("]");
1294      }
1295    }
1296
1297    // The future may complete while calculating the toString, so we check once more to see if the
1298    // future is done
1299    if (isDone()) {
1300      // Truncate anything that was appended before realizing this future is done
1301      builder.delete(truncateLength, builder.length());
1302      addDoneString(builder);
1303    }
1304  }
1305
1306  @SuppressWarnings("CatchingUnchecked") // sneaky checked exception
1307  private void addDoneString(StringBuilder builder) {
1308    try {
1309      V value = getUninterruptibly(this);
1310      builder.append("SUCCESS, result=[");
1311      appendResultObject(builder, value);
1312      builder.append("]");
1313    } catch (ExecutionException e) {
1314      builder.append("FAILURE, cause=[").append(e.getCause()).append("]");
1315    } catch (CancellationException e) {
1316      builder.append("CANCELLED"); // shouldn't be reachable
1317    } catch (Exception e) { // sneaky checked exception
1318      builder.append("UNKNOWN, cause=[").append(e.getClass()).append(" thrown from get()]");
1319    }
1320  }
1321
1322  /**
1323   * Any object can be the result of a Future, and not every object has a reasonable toString()
1324   * implementation. Using a reconstruction of the default Object.toString() prevents OOMs and stack
1325   * overflows, and helps avoid sensitive data inadvertently ending up in exception messages.
1326   */
1327  private void appendResultObject(StringBuilder builder, @Nullable Object o) {
1328    if (o == null) {
1329      builder.append("null");
1330    } else if (o == this) {
1331      builder.append("this future");
1332    } else {
1333      builder
1334          .append(o.getClass().getName())
1335          .append("@")
1336          .append(Integer.toHexString(System.identityHashCode(o)));
1337    }
1338  }
1339
1340  /** Helper for printing user supplied objects into our toString method. */
1341  @SuppressWarnings("CatchingUnchecked") // sneaky checked exception
1342  private void appendUserObject(StringBuilder builder, @Nullable Object o) {
1343    // This is some basic recursion detection for when people create cycles via set/setFuture or
1344    // when deep chains of futures exist resulting in a StackOverflowError. We could detect
1345    // arbitrary cycles using a thread local but this should be a good enough solution (it is also
1346    // what jdk collections do in these cases)
1347    try {
1348      if (o == this) {
1349        builder.append("this future");
1350      } else {
1351        builder.append(o);
1352      }
1353    } catch (Throwable e) {
1354      /*
1355       * We want to catch (Exception | StackOverflowError), but we can't under environments where
1356       * StackOverflowError doesn't exist.
1357       */
1358      rethrowIfErrorOtherThanStackOverflow(e);
1359      // The Throwable is either a RuntimeException, an Error, or sneaky checked exception.
1360      //
1361      // Don't call getMessage or toString() on the exception, in case the exception thrown by the
1362      // user object is implemented with bugs similar to the user object.
1363      builder.append("Exception thrown from implementation: ").append(e.getClass());
1364    }
1365  }
1366
1367  /**
1368   * Submits the given runnable to the given {@link Executor} catching and logging all {@linkplain
1369   * RuntimeException runtime exceptions} thrown by the executor.
1370   */
1371  @SuppressWarnings("CatchingUnchecked") // sneaky checked exception
1372  private static void executeListener(Runnable runnable, Executor executor) {
1373    try {
1374      executor.execute(runnable);
1375    } catch (Exception e) { // sneaky checked exception
1376      // Log it and keep going -- bad runnable and/or executor. Don't punish the other runnables if
1377      // we're given a bad one. We only catch Exception because we want Errors to propagate up.
1378      log.get()
1379          .log(
1380              SEVERE,
1381              "RuntimeException while executing runnable "
1382                  + runnable
1383                  + " with executor "
1384                  + executor,
1385              e);
1386    }
1387  }
1388
1389  private abstract static class AtomicHelper {
1390    /** Non-volatile write of the thread to the {@link Waiter#thread} field. */
1391    abstract void putThread(Waiter waiter, Thread newValue);
1392
1393    /** Non-volatile write of the waiter to the {@link Waiter#next} field. */
1394    abstract void putNext(Waiter waiter, @Nullable Waiter newValue);
1395
1396    /** Performs a CAS operation on the {@link AbstractFuture#waiters} field. */
1397    abstract boolean casWaiters(
1398        AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Waiter expect, @Nullable Waiter update);
1399
1400    /** Performs a CAS operation on the {@link AbstractFuture#listeners} field. */
1401    abstract boolean casListeners(
1402        AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Listener expect, Listener update);
1403
1404    /** Performs a GAS operation on the {@link AbstractFuture#waiters} field. */
1405    abstract @Nullable Waiter gasWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, Waiter update);
1406
1407    /** Performs a GAS operation on the {@link AbstractFuture#listeners} field. */
1408    abstract @Nullable Listener gasListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, Listener update);
1409
1410    /** Performs a CAS operation on the {@link AbstractFuture#value} field. */
1411    abstract boolean casValue(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Object expect, Object update);
1412  }
1413
1414  /**
1415   * {@link AtomicHelper} based on {@link sun.misc.Unsafe}.
1416   *
1417   * <p>Static initialization of this class will fail if the {@link sun.misc.Unsafe} object cannot
1418   * be accessed.
1419   */
1420  @SuppressWarnings("SunApi") // b/345822163
1421  private static final class UnsafeAtomicHelper extends AtomicHelper {
1422    static final Unsafe UNSAFE;
1423    static final long LISTENERS_OFFSET;
1424    static final long WAITERS_OFFSET;
1425    static final long VALUE_OFFSET;
1426    static final long WAITER_THREAD_OFFSET;
1427    static final long WAITER_NEXT_OFFSET;
1428
1429    static {
1430      Unsafe unsafe = null;
1431      try {
1432        unsafe = Unsafe.getUnsafe();
1433      } catch (SecurityException tryReflectionInstead) {
1434        try {
1435          unsafe =
1436              doPrivileged(
1437                  (PrivilegedExceptionAction<Unsafe>)
1438                      () -> {
1439                        Class<Unsafe> k = Unsafe.class;
1440                        for (Field f : k.getDeclaredFields()) {
1441                          f.setAccessible(true);
1442                          Object x = f.get(null);
1443                          if (k.isInstance(x)) {
1444                            return k.cast(x);
1445                          }
1446                        }
1447                        throw new NoSuchFieldError("the Unsafe");
1448                      });
1449        } catch (PrivilegedActionException e) {
1450          throw new RuntimeException("Could not initialize intrinsics", e.getCause());
1451        }
1452      }
1453      try {
1454        Class<?> abstractFuture = AbstractFuture.class;
1455        WAITERS_OFFSET = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(abstractFuture.getDeclaredField("waiters"));
1456        LISTENERS_OFFSET = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(abstractFuture.getDeclaredField("listeners"));
1457        VALUE_OFFSET = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(abstractFuture.getDeclaredField("value"));
1458        WAITER_THREAD_OFFSET = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(Waiter.class.getDeclaredField("thread"));
1459        WAITER_NEXT_OFFSET = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(Waiter.class.getDeclaredField("next"));
1460        UNSAFE = unsafe;
1461      } catch (NoSuchFieldException e) {
1462        throw new RuntimeException(e);
1463      }
1464    }
1465
1466    @Override
1467    void putThread(Waiter waiter, Thread newValue) {
1468      UNSAFE.putObject(waiter, WAITER_THREAD_OFFSET, newValue);
1469    }
1470
1471    @Override
1472    void putNext(Waiter waiter, @Nullable Waiter newValue) {
1473      UNSAFE.putObject(waiter, WAITER_NEXT_OFFSET, newValue);
1474    }
1475
1476    @Override
1477    boolean casWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Waiter expect, @Nullable Waiter update) {
1478      return UNSAFE.compareAndSwapObject(future, WAITERS_OFFSET, expect, update);
1479    }
1480
1481    @Override
1482    boolean casListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Listener expect, Listener update) {
1483      return UNSAFE.compareAndSwapObject(future, LISTENERS_OFFSET, expect, update);
1484    }
1485
1486    @Override
1487    @Nullable Listener gasListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, Listener update) {
1488      while (true) {
1489        Listener listener = future.listeners;
1490        if (update == listener) {
1491          return listener;
1492        }
1493        if (casListeners(future, listener, update)) {
1494          return listener;
1495        }
1496      }
1497    }
1498
1499    @Override
1500    @Nullable Waiter gasWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, Waiter update) {
1501      while (true) {
1502        Waiter waiter = future.waiters;
1503        if (update == waiter) {
1504          return waiter;
1505        }
1506        if (casWaiters(future, waiter, update)) {
1507          return waiter;
1508        }
1509      }
1510    }
1511
1512    @Override
1513    boolean casValue(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Object expect, Object update) {
1514      return UNSAFE.compareAndSwapObject(future, VALUE_OFFSET, expect, update);
1515    }
1516  }
1517
1518  /** {@link AtomicHelper} based on {@link AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater}. */
1519  private static final class AtomicReferenceFieldUpdaterAtomicHelper extends AtomicHelper {
1520    private static final AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<Waiter, @Nullable Thread> waiterThreadUpdater =
1521        AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater.<Waiter, @Nullable Thread>newUpdater(
1522            Waiter.class, Thread.class, "thread");
1523    private static final AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<Waiter, @Nullable Waiter> waiterNextUpdater =
1524        AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater.<Waiter, @Nullable Waiter>newUpdater(
1525            Waiter.class, Waiter.class, "next");
1526    private static final AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<? super AbstractFuture<?>, @Nullable Waiter>
1527        waitersUpdater = waitersUpdaterFromWithinAbstractFuture();
1528    private static final AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<? super AbstractFuture<?>, @Nullable Listener>
1529        listenersUpdater = listenersUpdaterFromWithinAbstractFuture();
1530    private static final AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<? super AbstractFuture<?>, @Nullable Object>
1531        valueUpdater = valueUpdaterFromWithinAbstractFuture();
1532
1533    @Override
1534    void putThread(Waiter waiter, Thread newValue) {
1535      waiterThreadUpdater.lazySet(waiter, newValue);
1536    }
1537
1538    @Override
1539    void putNext(Waiter waiter, @Nullable Waiter newValue) {
1540      waiterNextUpdater.lazySet(waiter, newValue);
1541    }
1542
1543    @Override
1544    boolean casWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Waiter expect, @Nullable Waiter update) {
1545      return waitersUpdater.compareAndSet(future, expect, update);
1546    }
1547
1548    @Override
1549    boolean casListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Listener expect, Listener update) {
1550      return listenersUpdater.compareAndSet(future, expect, update);
1551    }
1552
1553    @Override
1554    @Nullable Listener gasListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, Listener update) {
1555      return listenersUpdater.getAndSet(future, update);
1556    }
1557
1558    @Override
1559    @Nullable Waiter gasWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, Waiter update) {
1560      return waitersUpdater.getAndSet(future, update);
1561    }
1562
1563    @Override
1564    boolean casValue(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Object expect, Object update) {
1565      return valueUpdater.compareAndSet(future, expect, update);
1566    }
1567  }
1568
1569  /**
1570   * Returns an {@link AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater} for {@link #waiters}.
1571   *
1572   * <p>The creation of the updater has to happen directly inside {@link AbstractFuture}, as
1573   * discussed in {@link #methodHandlesLookupFromWithinAbstractFuture}.
1574   */
1575  private static AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<? super AbstractFuture<?>, @Nullable Waiter>
1576      waitersUpdaterFromWithinAbstractFuture() {
1577    return newUpdater(AbstractFuture.class, Waiter.class, "waiters");
1578  }
1579
1580  /**
1581   * Returns an {@link AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater} for {@link #listeners}.
1582   *
1583   * <p>The creation of the updater has to happen directly inside {@link AbstractFuture}, as
1584   * discussed in {@link #methodHandlesLookupFromWithinAbstractFuture}.
1585   */
1586  private static AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<? super AbstractFuture<?>, @Nullable Listener>
1587      listenersUpdaterFromWithinAbstractFuture() {
1588    return newUpdater(AbstractFuture.class, Listener.class, "listeners");
1589  }
1590
1591  /**
1592   * Returns an {@link AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater} for {@link #value}.
1593   *
1594   * <p>The creation of the updater has to happen directly inside {@link AbstractFuture}, as
1595   * discussed in {@link #methodHandlesLookupFromWithinAbstractFuture}.
1596   */
1597  private static AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater<? super AbstractFuture<?>, @Nullable Object>
1598      valueUpdaterFromWithinAbstractFuture() {
1599    return newUpdater(AbstractFuture.class, Object.class, "value");
1600  }
1601
1602  /**
1603   * {@link AtomicHelper} based on {@code synchronized} and volatile writes.
1604   *
1605   * <p>This is an implementation of last resort for when certain basic VM features are broken (like
1606   * AtomicReferenceFieldUpdater).
1607   */
1608  private static final class SynchronizedHelper extends AtomicHelper {
1609    @Override
1610    void putThread(Waiter waiter, Thread newValue) {
1611      waiter.thread = newValue;
1612    }
1613
1614    @Override
1615    void putNext(Waiter waiter, @Nullable Waiter newValue) {
1616      waiter.next = newValue;
1617    }
1618
1619    @Override
1620    boolean casWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Waiter expect, @Nullable Waiter update) {
1621      synchronized (future) {
1622        if (future.waiters == expect) {
1623          future.waiters = update;
1624          return true;
1625        }
1626        return false;
1627      }
1628    }
1629
1630    @Override
1631    boolean casListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Listener expect, Listener update) {
1632      synchronized (future) {
1633        if (future.listeners == expect) {
1634          future.listeners = update;
1635          return true;
1636        }
1637        return false;
1638      }
1639    }
1640
1641    @Override
1642    @Nullable Listener gasListeners(AbstractFuture<?> future, Listener update) {
1643      synchronized (future) {
1644        Listener old = future.listeners;
1645        if (old != update) {
1646          future.listeners = update;
1647        }
1648        return old;
1649      }
1650    }
1651
1652    @Override
1653    @Nullable Waiter gasWaiters(AbstractFuture<?> future, Waiter update) {
1654      synchronized (future) {
1655        Waiter old = future.waiters;
1656        if (old != update) {
1657          future.waiters = update;
1658        }
1659        return old;
1660      }
1661    }
1662
1663    @Override
1664    boolean casValue(AbstractFuture<?> future, @Nullable Object expect, Object update) {
1665      synchronized (future) {
1666        if (future.value == expect) {
1667          future.value = update;
1668          return true;
1669        }
1670        return false;
1671      }
1672    }
1673  }
1674
1675  private static CancellationException cancellationExceptionWithCause(
1676      String message, @Nullable Throwable cause) {
1677    CancellationException exception = new CancellationException(message);
1678    exception.initCause(cause);
1679    return exception;
1680  }
1681}
